newsitem.title: UK: Cuba, Brazil cited in fresh sugar freight orders.
newsitem.headline: Cuba, Brazil cited in fresh sugar freight orders.

text.p: Cuba featured heavily on the sugar freight market on Tuesday but demand was also cited for Brazil with the main interest for bulk cargoes, shipbrokers said on Tuesday.
Pacol was in the market for a prompt 25,000 tonnes of bulk sugar from Cuba to Black Sea and was said to have fixed a prompt 14,000-tonne parcel for the same run.
Vitol quoted for 20/23,000 tonnes in bulk from Maceio to the Egyptian Med, Black Sea or Baltic for May 5/15.
Cargill entered the market with a new order for 14,000 tonnes min/max bulk sugar from Maceio, Recife, Paranagua or Santos to the same set of destination options for May 5/10.
Cargill also quoted for 12/14,000 tonnes in bulk from Thailand to Indonesia for mid-May and 16,800 tonnes from Rio Haina to US Gulf/Atlantic for May 13/20.
Czarnikow Rionda was open for 19,000 tonnes of bulk sugar from Puerto Quetzal to US Gulf/Atlantic for the end of May.

Of the day's firmer business, Genoc was said to have fixed a 14,000-tonne bulk cargo from Cuba to the Egyptian Med, Black Sea or Baltic for May and was still open with 25/30,000 tonnes on the same run, again for May.
Shipbrokers said Benham booked tonnage for 7/10,000 tonnes of bulk sugar from Georgetown to US Gulf/Atlantic for early May and Kerry Trading 10,000 tonnes from Thailand to south Korea for early May.
Seabon fixed the 1970-built Nektar to ship 14,000 tonnes in bags prompt from the EU to Iran at $44.00.
In other news, Egypt has agreed to resell some of its Brazilian raw sugar contracts because of a local surplus.
Egyptian companies contracted to buy about 500,000 tonnes of raws and some deliveries will be deferred to March 1998 from July 1997.
The International Sugar Organization (ISO) said Russia was once again the largest country of destination for Cuban sugar in 1996, more than doubling its imports compared with 1995
Russia imported 1.83 million tonnes of Cuban raws last year after 722,051 in 1995, the ISO said.
